content.p: Identify which of these vector fields \mathbf{F}_1, \mathbf{F}_2 is a gradient vector field. Then, for your choice of \mathbf{F}_i, identify a potential function f(x,y) so that \mathbf{F}_i=\nabla f(x,y).

outtro.p: \mathbf{F} = \langle {{fx}}, {{fy}} \rangle is a gradient vector field of f(x,y)={{F}}, since {{fx}}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x} [ {{F}} ], and {{fy}}=\frac{\partial}{\partial y} [ {{F}} ].

content.p: Consider the function and vector field f, \mathbf{F}=\nabla f you found above. Let C be an oriented curve parameterized by \mathbf{r}(t) = \left\langle{{xt}}, {{yt}}\right\rangle, {{a}}\leq t \leq {{b}}.
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals to compute \displaystyle \int_{C } \mathbf{F} \ d\mathbf{s}.
